thread.title_full: Is your credit card doing you damage?

author: Sophie Elsworth
title: Is your credit card doing you damage?
text:
Using your credit card too much is a sign it’s doing you damage.
Sophie Elsworth SIGNING up to a credit card is a relatively pain-free process but often its not too long before it starts causing the undisciplined user damage.
The little piece of plastic can quickly cause of lot of heartache — the most obvious sign is when you do not pay your balance off in full every month.
Here’s five signs your credit card is doing you damage.
1. Interest charges
If you fail to pay off your card off in full every month you are the sort of customer financial institutions like — a revolver — a card user who carries their balance over from month to the next.
This means you are paying interest on your debt and it’s not cheap.
Figures from financial comparison website Finder.com.au show the average credit card rate is 17 per cent but shop around and you can get rates as low as 8 per cent.
COMPARE LOW RATE CARDS
2. Fees
Consumers often get sucked in by the rewards and offers that come with credit cards and forget to look into the fees associated with using plastic.
Finder spokeswoman Michelle Hutchison says many users are simply wasting their money by paying annual fees.
“It’s generally worthwhile using a credit card rewards program if you spend more than $14,000 per year on your card,’’ she says.
“If you don’t use your card often, you pay off your balance in full each month and you spend less than $14,000 per year on your card then you shouldn’t need to pay an annual fee.”
On their database they have more than 50 cards that do not have annual fees.
COMPARE INTEREST FREE CARDS
Finder.com.au’s Michelle Hutchison says don’t waste your money on annual fees. Source: Supplied
3. Cash advances
These sting badly.
Cash advance rates range anywhere from about 19 to 30 per cent and you’ll most likely get hit with a cash advance withdrawal fee of about $3 or up to five per cent of the amount withdrawn — whichever is greater.
Avoid these at all costs.
4. Using your card too much
If you find you’re constantly spending on your card to survive each week then alarm bells should be ringing.
Try leaving your card at home or chop it up — this will put an automatic stop to you spending.
If you do cut it up make sure you contact your credit card provider.
The Australian Bankers’ Association’s spokeswoman Diane Tate says cutting it up won’t solve all your problems.
“If you’re finding it hard to manage your finances, you may be able to put a temporary hold on your credit card account or you could close your account,’’ she says.
“Don’t just cut up your credit card — this doesn’t close your account and you may continue to have a debt with your provider.”
5. Credit file
Every time you apply for credit a mark will be put on your file.
Free credit score service Credit Savvy found that the average credit score of people with five or more credit card inquiries on file was 128 points lower than those without any inquiries, while consumers with more than seven credit card inquiries on file were 187 points worse off.
So think twice before signing up to credit because it will diminish your chances of being able to apply for a loan down the track.
Hutchison says, “try not to apply for a new credit card in less than a year of opening your last card.”
